RegexRule.Notes:
Targeting DES hashes in *passwd and *shadow files. For example Apache webserver, Linux /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow, ProFTPd ftpd.passwd
Notes to understand the regex: - Excluding lines starting with : or # as comments are allowed in some contexts - excluding { and $ as variables may be used in some contexts - Passwd files use 'x' in the password field to refer to the shadow file - Shadow files use ! and * to disable accounts and to force people to update their passwords. - DES hashes are 13 characters long, the two first characters are the salt.

RegexRule.Notes:
Targeting bcrypt password hash format. Mainly used in Linux /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow files. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bcrypt
Example $2y$10$vwDJYAy9lHOnfDERU6H0eOo5.tZsfKD9Pn46E4RouhAwGbcwt.t1W Salt is 22 chars and hash is 31 chars

RegexRule.Notes: Targeting password like variables in common bash scripts. Note: .env files are a bit special and are for example used by Docker as well. They are properties-like, so the '.env' part could possibly be extracted and converted into a StructuralRule if we could force interpret specific files on rule-level.
Anti-pattern for rule 6BCA96E5-345F-40E2-8FB1-F76C15ECC96A

RegexRule.Notes: Targeting hardcoded JWT tokens, defined in RFC 7519. Except for the URL safe base64 charset and the dots, there are not many requirements on the values on a JWT. To avoid noise: - Requiring the header and body sections to start with e(yJ|yA|wo|wk|w0). Most common is eyJ, which is JWTs starting with {"[A-Za-z] The others are intended to cover variations of json with newline, spaces and tabs - Requiring the header to be >20 chars as that's a header with only 'alg' set - Requiring the body to be >20 chars, as JWTs would have at least one claim

Description.Abstract: Storing passwords or password details in plain text anywhere in the system or system code may compromise system security in a way that cannot be easily remedied.
Description.Explanation:
It is never a good idea to hardcode a password. Storing password details within comments is equivalent to hardcoding passwords. Not only does it allow all of the project's developers to view the password, it also makes fixing the problem extremely difficult. After the code is in production, the password is now leaked to the outside world and cannot be protected or changed without patching the software. If the account protected by the password is compromised, the owners of the system must choose between security and availability. In this case, the password details appear in the comment in on line . Example: The following comment specifies the default password to connect to a database: 
...
// Default username for database connection is "scott"
// Default password for database connection is "tiger"
...
This code will run successfully, but anyone who has access to it will have access to the password. An employee with access to this information can use it to break into the system.
Description.Recommendations: Passwords should never be hardcoded and should generally be obfuscated and managed in an external source. Storing passwords in plain text anywhere on the system allows anyone with sufficient permissions to read and potentially misuse the password.

Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium 24 + 2

Reference.Title: Information Leakage (WASC-13)
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium Version 2.00

Description.Abstract: <Paragraph>Bidirectional control characters in source code can lead to trojan source attacks.<AltParagraph>Bidirectional control characters in source code can lead to trojan source attacks.</AltParagraph></Paragraph>
Description.Recommendations: Fortify recommends the following: (1) Identify all Unicode bidirectional (BiDi) control characters in source code files within a software supply chain. (2) Review and eliminate all unnecessary BiDi control characters from source files. (3) Report any identified malicious Unicode BiDi control character usage to your cyber security team. (4) Review compilers, interpreters, and source code/viewers editors for vulnerabilities related to either interpreting or viewing Unicode BiDi control characters. (5) Apply any necessary patches for compilers, interpreters, and source code editors/viewers.

Reference.Title: Trojan Source: Invisible Vulnerabilities
Reference.Author: Nicholas Boucher, and R. Anderson

Reference.Title: A1 Injection
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - OWASP Top 10 2017

Reference.Title: A03 Injection
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - OWASP Top 10 2021

Description.Abstract: Hardcoded API credentials can compromise system security in a way that is not easy to remedy.
Description.Explanation: Never hardcode credentials, including usernames, passwords, API keys, API secrets, and API Tokens. Not only are hardcoded credentials visible to all of the project developers, they are extremely difficult to update. After the code is in production, the credentials cannot be changed without patching the software. If the credentials are compromised, the organization must choose between security and system availability.
Description.Recommendations: Make sure that API credentials are either loaded from a configuration file that is only available in the runtime environment or from environment variables.

Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium 24 + 2

Reference.Title: Insufficient Authentication (WASC-01)
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium Version 2.00

Description.Abstract: Hardcoded passwords can compromise system security in a way that is difficult to remedy.
Description.Explanation:
Never hardcode passwords. Not only does it expose the password to all of the project's developers, it also makes fixing the problem extremely difficult. After the code is in production, a program patch is probably the only way to change the password. If the account protected by the password is compromised, the organization must choose between security and system availability. Example: The following URL uses a hardcoded password: 
...
https://user:secretpassword@example.com
...
Description.Recommendations: Never hardcode passwords. Always obfuscate and manage passwords in an external source. Storing passwords in plain text anywhere on the system enables anyone with sufficient permissions to read and potentially misuse the password.

Reference.Title: Insufficient Authentication
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium 24 + 2

Reference.Title: Insufficient Authentication (WASC-01)
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium Version 2.00

Description.Abstract: Hardcoded encryption keys can compromise security in a way that is not easy to remedy.
Description.Explanation:
Never hardcode an encryption key because it makes the encryption key visible to all of the project's developers, and makes fixing the problem extremely difficult. Changing the encryption key after the code is in production requires a software patch. If the account that the encryption key protects is compromised, the organization must choose between security and system availability. In this case, an encryption key is located in on line . Example 1: The following example shows an encryption key inside a .pem file: 
...
-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
MIICXwIBAAKBgQCtVacMo+w+TFOm0p8MlBWvwXtVRpF28V+o0RNPx5x/1TJTlKEl
...
DiJPJY2LNBQ7jS685mb6650JdvH8uQl6oeJ/aUmq63o2zOw=
-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
...
Anyone with access to the code can see the encryption key. After the application has shipped, there is no way to change the encryption key unless the program is patched. An employee with access to this information can use it to break into the system. Any attacker with access to the application executable can extract the encryption key value.
Description.Recommendations: Never check in encryption keys to your source control system, and never hardcode them. Always obfuscate and manage encryption keys in an external source. Storing encryption keys in plain text anywhere on the system enables anyone with sufficient permissions to read and potentially misuse the encryption key.

Description.Abstract: Hardcoded encryption keys can compromise security in a way that is not easy to remedy.
Description.Explanation: Never hardcode an encryption key because it makes the encryption key visible to all of the project's developers, and makes fixing the problem extremely difficult. Changing the encryption key after the code is in production requires a software patch. If the account that the encryption key protects is compromised, the organization must choose between security and system availability. In this case, the file likely contains an encryption key. Example 1: The Public-Key Cryptography Standards #12 KeyStore is a common cryptographic bundle file format, which commonly contains SSL/TLS certificates and corresponding private keys. It uses file name extensions .pkcs12, .p12, and pfx. Anyone with access to the code can see the encryption key. After the application has shipped, there is no way to change the encryption key unless the program is patched. An employee with access to this information can use it to break into the system. Any attacker with access to the application executable can extract the encryption key value.
Description.Recommendations: Never check in encryption keys to your source control system, and never hardcode them. Always obfuscate and manage encryption keys in an external source. Storing encryption keys in plain text anywhere on the system enables anyone with sufficient permissions to read and potentially misuse the encryption key.

Description.Abstract: There is no description available for this vulnerability category.
Description.Explanation: Please contact Micro Focus Fortify for further details.
Description.Recommendations: Please contact Micro Focus Fortify for further details.

Description.Abstract: Storing a password database in source code is never a good idea. Even though it's encrypted, this method might expose you to some risks.
Description.Explanation:
A password database is an encrypted database for storing passwords and other sensitive information. There are several problems with storing a password database together with source code:
1. There is no way for your organization to control the strength of the master password used for the database, allowing the use of weak passwords.
2. If the password database is used to share passwords among team members, it exposes your organization to insider threats as anyone can then anonymously access the services that the credentials. When a team member leaves the organization, all the shared passwords needs to be changed, which is much more time consuming compared to disabling the leaving member's personal accounts.
3. If the password database is used to bundle passwords with your delivered product, it either means using the same password for all customers or requiring complex logic to generate unique passwords for each customer. Either way exposes a risk for your customers.
4. If you are using a version control system, such as git, you can be vulnerable to attacks against older versions of the password database. The older version might exist from a time when a weak password was used, or when an older version of the password management software was used that might have created an insecure password database.
5. Storing the password database in a source code directory increases the risk of it accidentally being included in built artifacts that are shipped to customers.
If the password database is leaked, it is susceptible to brute-force attacks to crack the password. Depending on the strength of encryption and the master key used, the risk may be significant.
Description.Recommendations:
Do not store your password database together with your source code.
- Create individual accounts for all team members and avoid sharing credentials. - Store your password databases in a secure location that is not version controlled. - Configure individual passwords for each customer.
If the password database has been part of version control, you should also:
- If possible, remove it from the version control history - Change the passwords on all the accounts stored (both current and in the history) in the password database.

Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium Version 2.00

Description.Abstract: Obscuring a password with trivial encoding does not protect the password.
Description.Explanation:
Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plain text in an application's properties or configuration file. A programmer can attempt to remedy the password management problem by obscuring the password with an encoding function, such as base64 encoding, but this does not adequately protect the password. Example 1: The following Linux shadow file contains a password that is using the weak encryption algorithm DES. 
...
root:qFio7llfVKk.s:19033:0:99999:7:::
...
The DES algorithm has proven weak, and can be brute-forced in a matter of days.
Description.Recommendations:
A password should never be stored in plain text. An administrator should be required to enter the password when the system starts. If that approach is impractical, a less secure but often adequate solution is to obfuscate the password and scatter the de-obfuscation material around the system so that an attacker has to obtain and correctly combine multiple system resources to decipher the password. Example 2: The following Linux shadow file uses SHA512 to store the password in a hash format. 
...
root:$6$g0BoSug7ptXNEogi$Kw06M9FgAWhrs1XrVvN5kV/TSh.niiTvce.pzxrciaFbDUAxGQWo3XyIi.vSW70F3acktQEyx84uXCTp5eWx//:18745:0:99999:7:::
...

Reference.Title: Information Leakage
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium 24 + 2

Reference.Title: Information Leakage (WASC-13)
Reference.Author: Standards Mapping - Web Application Security Consortium Version 2.00

Description.Abstract: Hardcoded passwords can compromise system security in a way that is difficult to remedy.
Description.Explanation: Never hardcode passwords. Not only does it expose the password to all of the project's developers, it also makes fixing the problem extremely difficult. After the code is in production, a program patch is probably the only way to change the password. If the account the password protects is compromised, the system owners must choose between security and availability. <Paragraph> A password was configured to access a resource in <Replace key="PrimaryLocation.file"/> on line <Replace key="PrimaryLocation.line"/>. </Paragraph>
Description.Recommendations: Never hardcode password. Passwords should generally be obfuscated and managed in an external source. Storing passwords in plain text anywhere on the system allows anyone with sufficient permissions to read and potentially misuse the password.

mask:Mask.name: Targeted
mask:Mask.mask:Description: This setting provides the source code analyzer with rules within categories that have been proven to be high priority issues across multiple industries and within a variety of environments. They should be used to discover a limited set of well-known, critical security issues.

mask:Mask.name: Broad
mask:Mask.mask:Description: This setting provides the source code analyzer with the most comprehensive set of rules. It should be used to discover a broad set of security issues to be audited.

mask:Mask.name: Medium
mask:Mask.mask:Description: This setting provides the source code analyzer with rules that strike a balance between producing results that detail all potential issues and a targeted set of possible vulnerabilities.
